node.title: Why houses are expensive and likely to become more so
node.description: Australia's surging house prices are a big problem for people who don't already own one, or more. And, while most people agree something needs to be done to make housing more affordable, there's a big split about what the most effective solutions willÂ be.
node.content:
["An at-times-testy\u00a0debate took place at a committee hearing into why Australia has such unaffordable housing and what to do about it.", "On one side was the committee chair, Sydney-based Liberal MP Jason Falinski, who represents Mackellar, an electorate covering\u00a0Sydney's upper northern beaches \u2014\u00a0some of the most expensive real estate in the nation.", "On the other was Luci Ellis, assistant governor (economic) at the Reserve Bank, who has been involved in much of the bank's housing research for three\u00a0decades.", "The point of difference? Are houses like mandarins? Or, to translate the analogy, do the usual economic rules of supply and demand apply to housing, or are there other factors explaining price movements that don't exist for\u00a0most everyday goods?", "
No shortage of homes: RBA
", "First a bit of essential context.", "The debate arose because of the Reserve Bank's submission and previous evidence to the inquiry, repeated yesterday, that quashed the suggestion that bottlenecks in new housing supply \u2014\u00a0such as planning or zoning regulations \u2014\u00a0were the main culprits for Australia's spectacular property price boom since the late 1990s.", "\"In Australia, additions to the housing stock have run ahead of population growth for a number of years,\" Dr Ellis said\u00a0in her opening statement.", "\"This led to higher vacancy rates in the largest capital cities. Vacancy rates in the two largest cities rose further following the onset of the pandemic.\u00a0With the international border closed, population growth dropped sharply.", "\"At the same time, the HomeBuilder subsidy and similar state-based grants have encouraged more home-building, and will for a while yet.", "It's a longer term trend I wrote about as far back as 2014 and 2015, even at the very beginning of the recent record-breaking home-building boom.", "Instead, the Reserve Bank essentially blamed\u00a0itself for the long-term run-up in home prices.", "\"At some level, that was our doing,\"\u00a0Dr Ellis admitted while arguing there was\u00a0not much it could have done differently.", "\"Financial deregulation in the 1980s and the global decline in inflation in the 1990s combined to reduce nominal interest rates,\" Dr Ellis explained.", "\"With lower interest rates, people could service a bigger mortgage with the same repayment.", "\"Some of this extra buying capacity financed an increase in the quality of the housing stock.", "\"But, because most of the housing stock was already in place, the main effect was to bid up housing prices; this was captured in land prices.\"", "
'Houses are not mandarins'
", "", "
Unlike mandarins, houses do not grow on trees, with well-located land in short supply.(ABC: Jessica Hayes)
", "Mr Falinski, however, took issue with this theory, summing\u00a0up in this analogy during the bank regulator APRA's evidence, immediately prior to the RBA's appearance.", "\"The Reserve Bank said one of the reasons prices have expanded is because people can afford to borrow more money. Does that not strike you as a bizarre take on how market economics works?\" he asked a pair of somewhat bemused APRA officials.", "\"Let me give you this analogy. I went and bought fruit on the weekend and I paid about 75 cents per mandarin \u2014\u00a0and I don't know if I got a good deal or not \u2014\u00a0but when I got to the counter I still had money left over.", "When she appeared, it was apparent Dr Ellis had\u00a0been listening to the previous questioning of APRA.", "\"Houses are not mandarins. The land underneath them is very important,\" she responded.", "\"And the mandarins you buy this week are new mandarins and they're not the mandarins that you didn't buy last week. The mandarins last week are no longer available for sale because someone has eaten them, probably my children.\"", "
'All land is not created equal'
", "", "
Only a limited amount of land exists in locations with great views, or close to amenities, transport and\u00a0jobs.(ABC Central Coast: Sofie Wainwright)
", "Fundamentally, Dr Ellis explained, there is an inherent shortage of desirable land and people will pay whatever they can afford \u2014 generally how much they can borrow\u00a0\u2014 to get the most suitable property in the best location.", "\"All land is not created equal,\"\u00a0she argued.", "When the amount people can borrow increases, a new round of competition ensues to secure a more desirable residence, attracting investors who jump in to try to\u00a0catch a share of the capital gains.", "In response, Mr Falinski cited Texas in the US as a region where home prices are affordable relative to incomes \u2014\u00a0even in large, prosperous and growing cities \u2014\u00a0due to more liberal planning and zoning rules, although it also has a significant state land tax that is likely to contribute to this outcome.", "However, Dr Ellis pointed to geographical constraints as a \"more fundamental\" factor that make cities bounded by the ocean, mountains and other undevelopable areas such as national parks inherently more expensive, with cities including\u00a0Sydney, Auckland and Santiago cited as examples.", "", "
Auckland, like Sydney, is a harbour city and is also bordered\u00a0by steep terrain.(AP: Tourism Auckland)
", "
Why does this argument matter?
", "This is much more than an esoteric debate about economic theories of supply and demand, it has real consequences for what policies will work best to fix Australia's undoubted housing affordability problems.", "If Jason Falinski, many people in the building and development industries, and some economists \u2014\u00a0including former senior RBA researcher Peter Tulip\u00a0\u2014\u00a0are correct, then the best way to make homes cheaper is to reduce planning and zoning restrictions, allowing developers to build more new homes more quickly, pretty much wherever they want.", "However, if Dr Ellis, many other economists and urban planners are correct, then simply building more houses and apartments\u00a0will likely mainly\u00a0result in a larger number of still unaffordable homes.", "In the second case, the solution is much more painful for existing owners, real estate agents, developers\u00a0and, potentially, some aspiring buyers: reduce demand.", "And some of the mechanisms for this are extremely painful indeed.", "\"There are no examples, internationally, of large falls in nominal housing prices that have occurred, other than through significant reduction in capacity to pay, such as a recession and high unemployment,\" Dr Ellis argued.", "\"There's no example in Australia, or internationally, where supply expansion on its own [has] generated house pricing declines of a similar order of magnitude to the kinds of cycles in house prices that we've seen in recent years.\"", "
Is tax system creating 'artificial' demand for houses?
", "However, reducing housing demand need not be quite so painful in Australia, at least if you consider there may be extra demand generated primarily by financial, not residential, considerations.", "\"The combination of negative gearing with concessional capital gains means that it is very attractive to leverage into investor property,\" Dr Ellis observed.", "Labor MP Matt Thistlethwaite picked up on that theme in a pointed question to Dr Ellis.", "\"I think that is a conclusion that some may wish to draw,\" Dr Ellis\u00a0responded, in typically diplomatic RBA fashion.", "\"It is the system we have, and the question is: Can you get from here to there.\"", "Dr Ellis noted that some other countries were trying to address similar issues.", "\"One that we are watching over the next little while [is] to see how it plays out is New Zealand,\" she said.", "\"Their tax system was even more generous to investor property than ours.\u00a0For a long time, they didn't even have a capital gains tax. Their negative gearing was also quite generous, and they've tightened up a lot on that recently.\"", "The one area of consensus was that Australia's housing market cannot continue as it is, where, as Dr Ellis observed, \"the children of people who own homes can end up relatively easily becoming home owners, [while] people\u00a0whose parents rented are going to be in a much more difficult situation\".", "\"I can see that as being an attractive principle for public policy,\" Dr Ellis responded.", "\"Thank you. Dr Ellis, I will grab that statement because I know how hard it is for the Reserve Bank to opine on these things.\"", "While it may be difficult for the RBA to express a view on housing policies, history would suggest it's even harder for governments to change them to lower property prices and improve affordability, whether through more supply or less demand."]
